category_system.description: Portuguese profanity categorization system covering Lusophone variants and cultural contexts
category_system.methodology: Based on linguistic research across Portuguese-speaking countries and contemporary usage analysis

general.name: General Profanity
general.description: Common Portuguese swear words and mild expletives without specific targeting
general.examples_note: Basic profanity used for emphasis or frustration across Portuguese-speaking regions

subcategories.intensifiers: Words used to intensify other expressions

regional_variations.angola_mozambique: Colonial influence mixed with local taboos

scatological.name: Scatological Terms
scatological.description: References to bodily waste and related functions

subcategories.waste_references: Direct references to feces and urine

anatomical.name: Anatomical References
anatomical.description: Crude or inappropriate references to body parts
anatomical.examples_note: Body parts used inappropriately or crudely

subcategories.other_body_parts: Non-genital body parts used crudely (cu, rabo)

anatomical.cultural_notes: Brazilian Portuguese generally more tolerant of anatomical references than European Portuguese

sexual.name: Sexual Content
sexual.description: Words related to sexual acts, behavior, or sexually explicit content

derogatory.name: Derogatory Terms
derogatory.description: General insults and put-downs targeting individuals or groups

gender_specific.name: Gender-Specific Insults
gender_specific.description: Insults that specifically target based on gender

subcategories.sexual_behavior_judgment: Judging sexual behavior based on gender

gender_specific.cultural_context: Strong machismo traditions affect severity and usage patterns

lgbtq_slurs.name: LGBTQ+ Slurs
lgbtq_slurs.description: Derogatory terms targeting sexual orientation or gender identity
lgbtq_slurs.legal_considerations: May violate hate speech laws in Brazil and Portugal
lgbtq_slurs.social_impact: Causes significant harm to LGBTQ+ community

religious.name: Religious Profanity
religious.description: Blasphemous or sacrilegious language targeting religious beliefs
religious.cultural_context: Catholic influence varies by region and generation

racial_ethnic.name: Racial and Ethnic Slurs
racial_ethnic.description: Derogatory terms targeting racial or ethnic groups
racial_ethnic.historical_context: Legacy of colonialism and slavery affects severity

socioeconomic.name: Socioeconomic Discrimination
socioeconomic.description: Terms targeting social class or economic status

subcategories.class_discrimination: Upper class looking down on lower class

brazilian_specific.name: Brazilian Portuguese Specific
brazilian_specific.description: Profanity specific to Brazilian Portuguese culture and usage
brazilian_specific.examples_note: Terms that are particularly Brazilian in origin or usage

subcategories.carnival_culture: Terms from carnival and party culture

european_portuguese.name: European Portuguese Specific
european_portuguese.description: Profanity specific to European Portuguese culture
european_portuguese.examples_note: Terms more common or specific to Portugal

african_portuguese.name: African Portuguese Variants
african_portuguese.description: Profanity patterns in African Portuguese-speaking countries
african_portuguese.examples_note: Angola, Mozambique, and other African variants

1.description: Generally acceptable in informal settings but avoided in formal contexts
1.cultural_notes: May be used casually among friends, varies by region

2.description: Inappropriate in professional or mixed company, causes mild to moderate offense
2.cultural_notes: Avoided in formal situations and around older generations

3.description: Highly offensive and inappropriate in most contexts, causes significant offense
3.cultural_notes: Limited to very informal settings among close acquaintances

4.description: Extremely offensive, taboo in public discourse, may cause serious social consequences
4.cultural_notes: Hate speech and extremely vulgar terms, potentially illegal

cultural_considerations.regional_tolerance: Brazilian Portuguese generally more tolerant of profanity than European Portuguese
cultural_considerations.generational_differences: Younger generations more accepting, especially with anatomical references
cultural_considerations.religious_influence: Catholic heritage affects perception, stronger in rural areas
cultural_considerations.gender_expectations: Different social expectations for male vs female use of profanity
cultural_considerations.class_dynamics: Upper classes expected to use less profanity, working classes more tolerant
cultural_considerations.media_representation: Brazilian media more permissive than Portuguese media
cultural_considerations.colonial_legacy: Historical colonial relationships affect interregional sensitivities
cultural_considerations.machismo_culture: Traditional gender roles influence severity of gender-specific insults
